subject: UNICEF e-news: Demobilizing child soldiers
body:
UNICEF and Chad agree on demobilizing child soldiers
17 May 2007


 










Dear Andrew:
UNICEF and the Government of Chad have signed an accord to demobilize child soldiers throughout the country.
The agreement was signed last week by UNICEF Representative Stephen Adkisson and Chad’s Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Djidda Moussa Outman. It follows up commitments made by Chad in February at the ‘Free Children from War’ conference, which was held in Paris and organized by UNICEF and the French Government. 
That conference resulted in the Paris Principles, an agreement to end the use of children in armed forces or groups around the world. The new accord in Chad is seen as an important step toward putting the principles into practice. 
“It was a strong demonstration of will on the part of the Chadian Government to ensure that all children under the age of 18 will be removed from any kind of military service,” Mr. Adkisson said. Learn more about this landmark agreement.

Days of Peace’ in the Philippines!
For decades, a conflict between the government and the Moro Islamic Liberation Front has raged in the southern Philippines, leaving many children without access to essential immunization and nutrition services. But under an agreement between UNICEF and the rebel group, fighting was suspended recently so that health workers could carry out a two-week campaign known as ‘Days of Peace’. More...
‘Bling’ with a conscience
Wearing a lot of diamonds is known nowadays as ‘blinging’ – but there is also a growing awareness that many armed conflicts in Africa have been funded by the sale of diamonds. A new documentary, ‘Bling: A Planet Rock’, follows three hip-hop artists to war-torn Sierra Leone, where they gain a new understanding of what ‘blood diamonds’ are and how the diamond trade affects children.
